page.title: 12Ecology - Bird & Plant life.
page.content: The land in our area is chiefly rough grazing or moorland. Grouse are shot on the moors, once the open season begins on the 12th of August, "The Glorious 12th". Over recent years the Grouse population has diminished, chiefly because the practice of burning the moors to encourage new shoots to grow has become uncommon. Around the reservoirs there is an abundance of bird life such as Dippers, Lapwings and Kestrels. Wild grasses such as the great Millet, annual meadow grass, black grass and green pauicle grass grow here, interspursed with wild flowers. On the moors heather and bilberry are to be found, although the heather is less widespread than in times past. Animals to be seen include Rabbits, Foxes and less common Weasels or Stoats.
